author: Lindsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2019
review_content: I am one of a rare breed who uses a water tester to measure ppm in the water. Anything above 200 ppm is considered hazardous. Here in Washington, DC, the water typically falls between 167-182 ppm. When I first received the filter, it tested at an astronomical 1132 ppm. After running 4-6 gallons of water through the filter per instructions from the manufacturer (instructions I called to receive), the lowest I could get the ppm was 137. I thought I had a faulty filter, so I had requested a replacement, but I faced the same issue. It is deeply concerning to me that innocent people might be drinking this "filtered" water, believing the water to be clean, when the mineral content continues to test so high. I have simultaneously been testing bottled water, which every time has tested at zero (yay) and Brita filters, which are testing currently around 33 (still far better). First, I would say it is CRITICAL that consumers follow the instructions due to the extremely toxic water that will initially come through the filter -- remember it was 1,132 ppm and 200 ppm and above is considered hazardous. Second, I personally believe that having to run 4 to 6 GALLONS through the filter before it is said to work is rather extreme. I broke it down over two days because my dispenser isn't particularly fast flowing, so even conducting half of that amount took me an hour. Third, it ultimately did NOT filter the water, which is frightening. I am removing the filter completely and returning it for a refund, because drinking the tap is essentially the same, saves us $50, and removes the possibility of toxic exposure from the contents of the filter. I do believe this should be looked at more closely, because not everyone is actively testing the water and is relying on the company's word that water using this filter should be around 4 ppm (that is what I was told at least on a phone call with the company). On a positive note, the team at EveryDrop were wonderful and courteous, and I rather enjoyed working with them. They were as shocked as I was by the water testing results.
title: WARNING - When tested, this filter yields hazardous levels of PPM

review_content: I've been purchasing this filter for the past several years and have never had any issues until this past purchase. author: SaltySailor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2020
review_content: I had purchased some generic filters in the past and was curious to know if they actually worked or if they were a ripoff so I bought a total dissolved solids meter on Amazon for about $15 and tested the water.  Absolutely pure water does not conduct electricity.  As amount of impurities in that water increases (which also include good things such as minerals) its ability to conduct electricity also increases and a TDS meter measures this and translates it to parts per million of TDS.  Well those generic filters did not filter anything from the water as the TDS meter indicated the same ppm TDS for both samples.So I decided to go ahead and spend the extra money on a "quality" filter.  Well after installing and running 1 gallon through there was no change between tap water and the water coming our of my fridge.  Same results after 5 gallons.  Now 2 weeks later and the family using the water dispenser the water tests about 20 ppm less than tap water.  May tap tests at 340 ppm give or take 15 depending on the day.  I also tested demineralized water which came in at 3 ppm and bottled Dasani water which was 15 ppm.AN ABSOLUTE AND COMPLETE RIPOFF TAKING ADVANTAGE OF TRUSTING CUSTOMERS!!!  Essentially stealing your money and is criminal.Other reviews echo this same result.  I encourage everyone to also conduct this testing.  There should be a class action lawsuit...
title: Fails Impurity Testing - Not Much Better Than Tap Water - Complete Ripoff

author: D. S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2020
review_content: Overall, I have always bought these authentic Whirlpool filters, despite their price, because I had read horror stories about leaks with generic versions. I have never had a leak with a real Whirlpool filter.One problem I had this last time, which others have had, is that after the initial purge of 3 gallons, after a short while the water would start to trickle and then stop. Nothing. I read about air in the line, so I followed the instructions of dispensing water for 5 seconds, then waiting again for another 5 seconds before resuming, and repeating countless times. What a pain! But it continued to have the problem. After a few dispenses, the water would stop flowing.  I found that if I removed the filter and snapped it back in, it would work for a few times, but the water not coming from the dispenser would just keep on coming back, until it hardly worked at all.I figured there was air in the FILTER. So, I washed the exterior well, and then submerged it in a deep container full of water (I washed it so that any dirt or contamination would enter the filter). Sure enough, I could see air very slowly popping out of one of the two opening. A small bubble, then pop, then another, then another.  I left it submerged for several hours until I was sure that I saw no more bubbles (I would also occasionally agitate it to help the air escape).  I then reinstalled it, and it has worked flawlessly ever since.So, if you have the same problem, that would be my suggestion.UPDATE: This worked for a good while, and then the same issue. Somehow air keeps on infiltrating the filter and causing stoppage of the water flow. Take it out and water flower perfectly. Very frustrating to do this every week or two.

author: DS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: With the need to change refrigerator/icemaker filter on our fridge every six months (approximately, based on water usage through the door and icemaker usage), this filter has been great at conditioning the terrible Florida tap water into what tastes like pure spring water, no exaggeration!The downside is that the filters are twice as expensive as aftermarket filters which claim to be compatible and perform in a similar manner, however, using aftermarket filters while under factory warranty could result in some unintended consequences such as an overly picky technician or online repair representative giving "pushback" and trying to void the warranty for not using OEM filters.All in all, minus 2 stars for the very high price (it's not an Amazon thing, but a factory price issue for OEM filters), but high praise for the quality, fit/finish, and final taste of the water.Small note: This (and all similar filters) do *not* remove dissolved lime from the water.  That takes reverse osmosis filtration, so there can still be calcium/lime buildup in the refrigerator system or on the water outlet spout (in-door) over time.  That's easily cleaned by wiping with some vinegar, but the lime remains in the drinking water.  All of Florida's water comes through the Florida aquifer, deep  underground, and the calcium and lime dissolve into the water before it's ever pumped out of the ground and sent for processing into tap water.  The dissolved particles are too small to be removed by standar filtration.

author: Linda Delores Moore
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2021
review_content: I live in an area where carefully filtered water is an absolute must.  This fridge was crazy expensive, so I baby it. So I am careful to always check the indicator light inside the fridge.  But in approximately 6 months, it never came on!! That really bothered me.  So I started researching online.  I found sites and forums where people had had similar questions (apparently, this is a thing?) and did not know when they should change the filter.  The most useful advice I found was that you know the filter needs changing when the flow from the water-in-the-door isn't as fast as it was in the beginning.  I had not even noticed this because the reduction in flow had been so gradual.  So I changed the filter and the difference was immediately noticeable.  So, now I have put this filter on subscription and now I will replace it every time a new one is delivered.  Problem solved.The reason I gave it only 4 stars instead of 5 is that the relationship between the filter and the functionality of the fridge is not clearly explained by either provider -- not Whirlpool (the manufacturer of the fridge) nor by the manufacturer of the filter. Nothing is explained about what causes the light to come on or when it is suitable to change the filter.  And I don't know whose responsibility this ought to be. author: Kaleb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2019
review_content: First thing I want to point out is the other reviews on this item that talk about TDS. First and foremost you are not buying this filter to remove TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) you need a RO/RODI (Reverse osmosis) filter unit in order to remove TDS. At the most this filter is a sediment filter (removes undissolved solids) to a point and then uses a carbon block to remove other chemicals from the water (ex: Chlorine, smells, taste, etc.) Overall just makes the water a bit healthier and cleaner with a “better” taste apposed to tap. Also helps prevent larger particles from building up in the fridge without removing 100% of everything in the water. Again research RODI units if you want 100% “clean, 0 TDS” water.Other then that it does have a good taste to the water.My biggest complaint is the cost. On average they last 6 months at $50 not on sale that’s approx $8.35 a month excluding tax. For a water filter. Compared to other filter styles that don’t fit this filter. I personally plan on letting the fridge bypass the filter and doing my own DIY filter in-line before it gets to the fridge.
